article.title: A radio spectral index map and catalogue at 147-1400 MHz covering 80 per cent of the sky

multiple_choice_question.text: NVSS and TGSS (convolved at 45") are equally sensitive to sources with a spectral index of:
Which of the following source categories represents a matched source with other matched sources (but no unmatched sources) in the same island?
What is the approximate weighted mean spectral index value of the full detections (red) in the figure?
What is the general trend observed in the number density of faint/flat-spectrum sources in the catalogue?
choices: They are overrepresented compared to other spectral types.
They are underrepresented compared to other spectral types.
Their distribution shows no clear trend.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the comparison between the blue dots and the black line in the 150 MHz source counts plot suggest about the reprocessed TGSS catalogue at low flux densities?
choices: The reprocessed catalogue shows an excess of sources compared to the model.
The reprocessed catalogue shows a deficit of sources compared to the model.
The reprocessed catalogue closely matches the model source counts.
The reprocessed catalogue shows a random distribution of sources compared to the model.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of radio galaxy is source A most likely classified as based on the spectral index map?
Where are the regions with slightly less accurate astrometry primarily located?
choices: Close to the equator and at high declination
Close to the north pole and at very low declination

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the observed trend in the average spectral index with increasing flux density?
choices: The average spectral index becomes flatter.
The average spectral index becomes steeper.
The average spectral index remains constant.
The trend is not consistent across all flux density bins.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of radio galaxies tend to populate the top-left region of the plot, characterized by compact size and flat spectrum?
What is the general trend observed for the compactness parameter (C) of known pulsars?
choices: Most pulsars have C values significantly below 1.
Most pulsars have C values significantly above 1.
Pulsars show a uniform distribution of C values.
There is no clear trend in the C values of pulsars.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of pulsar population is most likely responsible for the observed excess of compact, steep-spectrum sources at low galactic latitude?
